A wire cutting ice, the forming of snow-balls, ice skating: all unfortunate regelation myths passed on from text-book writers to their readers, who then become writers ...(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regelation#Misconceptions)

- To depress the melting point of ice by 1 °C requires a pressure > 10 MPa: the equivalent of concentrating the weight of a 100 kg adult on less than 1 cm². The palm of a hand has a surface area of 20 - 50 cm². So, according to this video's theory, if you can support a weight of 2000 - 5000 kg (two to five cars!) in the palm of one hand, you might be able to exert enough pressure to make a snow ball when the temperature outside is -1 °C...

- Pressure (no matter how large) can not depress ice's melting point below - 22 °C, so at temperatures below - 22 °C ice should no longer be slippery(?) - tell that to the ice truckers of Alaska, or researchers in Antarctica ...

- Following Pascal's principle, liquids transmit pressure equally in all directions, so once any part of a snow ball melts due to external pressure applied by your hands, the entire ball should liquefy; similarly, an ice-skater's blade should sink all the way, until the sole of the shoe rests on the icy surface ...

- Pressure changes are transmitted with the speed of sound (in ice: 4 km/s): the wire cutting process should be indistinguishable from free fall, the wire always encountering only liquid drag, not solid resistance...

Before refrigeration in the early days of America. The bootleggers would go to the mountain top and collect snow. They would put the snow into a large open container, and shape it so they could then place a very large bucket of water into that hollowed space. This was so that they could create more ice without having to transport it. They would pour almost pure ethyl alcohol onto the snow, and cover the inner container, which would freeze to solid ice. The newly made ice would then be shaved to fill several more containers to repeat the process.

The whole purpose of this was to make ice cream.

However on cold nights there was zero penetration by the heavy long objects left on end on the ice.

I was looking at regelation in Wikipedia and noticed this...

"

Misconceptions

Ice skating is given as an example of regelation; however the pressure required is much greater than the weight of a skater. Additionally, regelation does not explain how one can ice skate at sub-zero (°C) temperatures.[4]


Weights suspended from a wire which cuts through ice, is an example given in old textbooks. Once again the pressure required far exceeds the force applied. Conduction of heat from the room through the metal wire is the correct explanation of this phenomenon.


Compaction and creation of snow balls is another example from old texts. Again the pressure required is far greater than can be applied by hand. A counter example is that cars do not melt snow as they run over it.

"So what gives ?

Then again, in the Wikipedia "TALK" portion, it says...

"The article contradicts itself: according to the introduction, a copper

complex. According to the 'misconceptions' paragraph it is an invalid

Because of regelation. This means that when the pressure from the wire was applied it made the ice melt. But when the wire went through the ice, there was no pressure which meant that the water re-froze.

The weighted wire provides a pressure on the ice.
That pressure lowers the melting point of the ice as it brings the water molecules closer together causing a state change from Ice to water.
The wire then passes through the water layer.
The ice at the top, no longer under pressure, and still at it's freezing point, refreezes.
It's called regelation and wikipedia probably has a better explanation

Copper indeed has much less SHC than the fishing line, but getting colder quicker actually works to its advantage. The colder it gets, the faster it sucks the heat in from the ambient, and it conducts it (much better than the fishing line would) towards the ice.
